The Staff of the Suisun-Solano Water Authority

Michael J. Messina, Director of Operations and Maintenance SID

James M. Mitchell, Safety Officer/Risk Manager

Suisun-Solano Water Authority

508 Elmira

Vacaville, CA 95687

(707) 448-6847

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



I. INTRODUCTION



The regulations governing the Risk Management Plan were compiled to help prevent or 

minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, flammable or explosive 

chemicals.



The chemical used by Suisun-Solano Water Authority (SSWA) which is regulated by this 

standard is Chlorine.  Chlorine is stored at the Cement Hill Water Treatment Plant and is 

used for the treatment of public drinking water for the city of Suisun.



It is the intent of the SSWA to comply with the regulations pertaining to management of 

acutely hazardous materials.  It is our policy to adhere

to all applicable federal and state 

rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle chlorine, the 

safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, the safe handling procedures that we 

use, and the training of our personnel.





II. MANAGEMENT SYSTEM



The designated position of overall responsibility for the development and integration of the 

risk management program elements is the Municipal & Industrial Operations 

Superintendent.





III. PREVENTION PROGRAM



Safety Information

Chlorine is the chemical regulated by this standard.  The Material Safety Data Sheet 

(MSDS) contained in the MSDS booklet contains information regarding:



? Toxicity

? Permissible exposure limit (PEL)

? Physical

? Corrosivity

? Thermal and chemical stability

? Reactivity



Chlorine is non-explosive and non-flammable; however, like oxygen, it is an oxidizer and 

is capable of supporting combustion of certain substances.  Chlorine has a characteristic 

penetrating and irritating odor.  The gas is greenish yellow in color and the liquid is clear 

amber.



The chlorine utilized at the Cement Hill Treatment Plant is isolated from other chemicals 

stored on site.  The possibility of mixing of incompatible chemicals is negligible.



1. MSDS:

MATERIAL SAFETY DATA SHEET

Chlorine



SECTION 1 - CHEMICAL PRODUCT AND COMPANY IDENTIFICATION

paper, production of chlorinated compounds

INVOLVING A SPILL OR LEAK, CALL

 

    U

.S.:        1-800-424-9300 - CHEMTREC

Canada:    1-613-996-6666 - CANUTEC





SECTION 2 - COMPOSITION / INFORMATION ON INGREDIENTS 



Hazardous Ingredient(s)    % (w/w)    ACGIH        CAS NO. 

Chlorine            99 - 100    TWA - 0.5 ppm    7782-50-5 

STEL - 1 ppm 





SECTION 3 - HAZARD IDENTIFICATION



Emergency Overview: Greenish-yellow gas or clear amber liquid (under pressure) with a 

pungent suffocating odor.  COMPRESSED GAS.  STRONG OXIDIZER.  Contact with 

combustible materials may cause fire or explosion.  Reacts violently or explosively with 

many substances.  Reacts with water to form corrosive hydrochloric and hypochlorous 

acids.  Confined space hazard.  VERY TOXIC.  May be fatal if inhaled.  Extremely 

irritating to the respiratory tract.  Causes lung injury and effects may be delayed.  

CORROSIVE to the eyes and skin.  Liquefied gas can cause frostbite and corrosive injury 

to the eyes and skin.  Burns and permanent damage, including blindness may result.  Very 

toxic to aquatic organisms.  Can cause damage to vegetation.  Read the entire MSDS for a 

more thorough evaluation of the hazards.

 

Potential Health Effects:

 

General: Chlorine normally exists as a gas at room temperature and the most important 

route of exposure is inhalation, followed by eye and skin exposures.  Liquefied chlorine 

can freeze skin tissues. 

Inhalation: Chlorine is a severe nose, throat and upper respiratory tract irritant.  People 

exposed to chlorine, even for short periods of time, can develop a tolerance to its odor and 

irritating properties.  In mild exposures, clinical signs include rhinorrhea, cough, headache, 

sore throat, chest pain, dyspnea, nausea and pulmonary function deficits.  After more 

severe exposures, clinical signs include rhinorrhea, ulcerative tracheobronchitis, 

pulmonary edema, respiratory failure and death.

 

The following is a listing of chlorine exposure thresholds and estimated clinical effects:

? 0.2 - 0.4 ppm - odor threshold (with considerable

variation among subjects) (decrease 

in odor perception occurs over time).

? 5 - 15 ppm - moderate irritation of the respiratory tract

? 30 ppm - immediate chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, cough

? 40 - 60 ppm - toxic pneumonitis and pulmonary edema

? 430 ppm - lethal over 30 minutes

? 1000 ppm - fatal within a few minutes 



Skin Contact: Airborne gas may irritate and burn the skin.  Direct contact with the 

liquefied gas escaping from its pressurized cylinder can cause frostbite.  Symptoms of mild 

frostbite include numbness, prickling and itching in the affected area.  Symptoms of more 

severe frostbite include a burning sensation and stiffness of the affected area.  The skin 

may become waxy white or yellow.

 

Eye Contact: Chlorine gas is a severe eye irritant.  Stinging, a burning sensation, rapid 

blinking, redness and watering of the eyes have been observed at concentrations of 1 ppm 

and higher.  Direct contact with liquefied chlorine escaping from its high-pressure cylinder 

may cause frostbite.  Burns and permanent damage, including blindness may result.

 

Ingestion: Ingestion is not an applicable route of exposure for gases.

 

Existing Medical Conditions Possibly Aggravated by Exposure: Asthma, bronchitis, 

emphysema and other lung diseases and chronic nose, sinus or throat, and cardiac 

conditions.

 

Chronic Effects: A small number of human population studies conducted have not shown 

significant respiratory system effects in workers with long-term, low-level (typically less 

than 1 ppm) chlorine exposure.  One study examined 332 workers exposed to time-

weighted average (TWA) concentrations of between 0.006 and 1.42 ppm (0.15-ppm 

average) for an average of 10.9 years.  No relationship was found between exposure to 

chlorine and the occurrence of colds, breathing difficulties, and abnormal heartbeat or 

chest pain.  Significant effects on lung function were not observed.  Studies of workers 

who have had experienced one or mo

re exposures to chlorine which produced short-term 

health effects tend to show long-term lung dysfunction.

 

Carcinogenicity: Chlorine is not classified as carcinogenic by ACGIH (American 

Conference of Governmental Industrial Hygienists) or IARC (International Agency for 

Research on Cancer), not regulated as carcinogens by OSHA (Occupational Safety and 

Health Administration), and not listed as carcinogens by NTP (National Toxicology 

Program).



 

SECTION 4 - FIRST AID MEASURES

 

Inhalation: Take proper precautions to ensure your own safety before attempting rescue 

(e.g., wear appropriate protective equipment, use the buddy system).  Remove source of 

contamination or move victim to fresh air.  If breathing is difficult, oxygen may be 

beneficial if administered by trained personnel, preferably on doctor's advice.  DO NOT 

allow victim to move about unnecessarily.  Symptoms of pulmonary edema can be delayed 

up to 48 hours after exposure.  Apply artificial respiration if victim is not breathing.  

Induce artificial respiration with the aid of a pocket mask equipped with a one-way valve 

or other proper respiratory medical device.  Give Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) if 

there is no pulse AND no breathing.  Obtain medical attention IMMEDIATELY. 



Skin Contact: Quickly remove victim from source of contamination and flush with 

lukewarm, gently flowing water for a minimum of 20 minutes.  Liquefied Gas: DO NOT 

attempt to rewarm the affected area on site.  DO NOT rub area or apply dry heat.  Gently 

remove clothing or jewelry that may restrict circulation.  Carefully cut around clothing that 

sticks to the skin and remove the rest of the garment.  Loosely cover the affected area with 

a sterile dressing.  DO NOT allow victim to drink alcohol or smoke.  Obtain medical 

attention IMMEDIATELY.

 

Eye Contact: Immediately flush eyes with lukewarm running water for a minimum of 20 

minutes.  If a burn exists, cover both eyes with a ster

ile dressing.  Obtain medical attention 

IMMEDIATELY.

 

Ingestion: Ingestion is not an applicable route of exposure for gases.

 

Note to Physicians: Following exposure the patient should be kept under medical review 

for at least 48 hours as delayed pulmonary edema may occur.



 

SECTION 5 - FIRE FIGHTING MEASURES 



Flash Point:    Does not burn, but is a strong oxidizer and a serious 

fire risk. 

Flammable Limits (Lower):        Not applicable 

Flammable Limits (Upper):        Not applicable 

Auto Ignition Temperature:        Not applicable 

Decomposition Temperature:    Not available 

Combustion and Thermal

Decomposition Products:    Toxic chemicals are formed when combustible 

materials burn in chlorine.  These may include 

corrosive hydrogen chloride gas, free chlorine gas 

and other chlorine compounds. 

Rate of Burning:            Not applicable 

Explosive Power:            Not applicable 

Sensitivity to Mechanical Impact:    Not sensitive

 

Fire and Explosion Hazards: Chlorine does not burn.  However, chlorine is a strong 

oxidizing agent and poses a serious fire and explosion risk because it promotes 

combustion, like oxygen.  Most combustible materials will ignite and/or burn in chlorine 

atmospheres, forming irritating and toxic gases.  Containers or cylinders may rupture 

violently due to over-pressurization, if exposed to fire or excessive heat for a sufficient 

period of time.  Intense local heat (above 200?C) on the steel walls of chlorine cylinders 

can cause an iron/chlorine fire resulting in rupture of the container.  Cylinder and ton 

containers will vent through fusible plugs at 71?C (160?F).  Chlorine gas is heavier than air 

and will collect and persist in pits, hollows, depressions, and other confined or low-lying 

areas.

 

Extinguishing Media: Use extinguishing media appropriate to surrounding fire 

conditions, such as dry chemical powder, carbon dioxide, or foam.

 

Fire Fighting Procedures: Apply water from as far a distance as possible, in flooding

quantities as a spray or fog to keep fire-exposed cylinders, containers or equipment cool 

and absorb heat, until well after the fire is out.  If there is a chlorine leak, stop the flow of 

gas, if this can be done safely.  A chlorine fire can be extinguished only by stopping the 

flow of chlorine gas.  Use water spray to protect personnel attempting to shut off the flow.  

Remove all flammable and combustible materials from the vicinity, especially oil and 

grease.  Use water with caution.  Do not apply water directly to the liquefied or gaseous 

chlorine.  Reverse flow into cylinder may cause rupture.  Take care not to block pressure 

relief valves.

 

Stay away from ends of tanks (but realize that shrapnel may travel in any direction).  In an 

advanced or massive fire, the area should be evacuated; use unmanned hoseholders or 

monitor nozzles.

 

Fire Fighting Protective Equipment: Use specialized protective equipment suitable for 

the situation.  Firefighter's normal protective clothing (Bunker Gear) will not provide 

adequate protection.  A full-body encapsulating chemical resistant suit with positive 

pressure self-contained breathing apparatus (MSHA/NIOSH approved or equivalent) may 

be necessary. 



Evacuation: If tank, rail car or tank truck is involved in a fire, ISOLATE for 800 meters 

(< mile) in all directions; also, consider initial evacuation for 800 meters (< mile) in all 

directions.

 

NOTE: Also see: "Section 10 - Stability and Reactivity". 





SECTION 6 - ACCIDENTAL RELEASE MEASURES 



Spills, Leaks, or Releases: 

? Restrict access to area until completion of clean up.  Ensure trained personnel conduct 

clean up.

? Wear adequate personal protective equipment including respiratory protection.

? Remove all combustible and flammable materials

? Remove all ignition sources (no smoking, flares, sparks or flames).  All equipment 

should be grounded.  Ventilate area.

? Stop leak if possible without personal risk.  Emergency

Materials Register: Y 



Right-To-Know: Illinois, Massachusetts, New Jersey, Pennsylvania 



EEC Classification: Toxic.  Irritant.  Dangerous for environment.



EINECS: 231-959-5 





SECTION 16 - OTHER INFORMATION 



The information contained herein is offered only as a guide to the handling of this specific 

material and has been prepared in good faith by technically knowledgeable personnel.  It is 

not intended to be all-inclusive and the manner and conditions of use and handling may 

involve other and additional considerations.  No warranty of any kind is given or implied 

and PIONEER will not be liable for any damages, losses, injuries or consequential 

damages that may result from the use of or reliance on any information contained herein.  

This Material Safety Data Sheet is valid for three years.

 

Revision Indicators: 

In the left margin indicates a revision or addition of information since the previous issue. 



National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Rating 

Hazardous Materials Identification System (HMIS) Rating 



NFPA        HMIS 

HEALTH             4        3 

FIRE                0        0 

REACTIVITY            0        0 

SPECIAL            oxidizer 



4 = Extreme/Severe

3 = High/Serious

2 = Moderate

1 = Slight

0 = Minimum





REFERENCE 



1. RTECS-Registry of Toxic Effects of Chemical Substances, Canadian Centre for 

Occupational Health and Safety RTECS database, National Institute for Occupational 

Safety and Health, U.S. Dept. of Health and Human Services, Cincinnati, Entry 

Update/ May 2002

2. Transport Of Hazardous Materials (49CFR), Canadian Centre for Occupational Health 

and Safety, Issue : 2002-2 (May, 2002)

3. The Chlorine Institute, Inc., "Molecular Chlorine: Health and Environmental Effects", 

Pamphlet 90, Edition 2, November 1998

4. "CHEMINFO", through "CCINFOdisc", Canadian Centre for Occupational Health and 

Safety, Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, (May, 2002).

5. Chemlist, STN Database, Chemical Abstract Service, Jul 2002

6. Chemical Hazards Response Inform

kits are available for handling 

chlorine leaks in cylinders, tank cars and tank trailers.  All personnel must be trained in 

their particular usage.  This information is available from the Chlorine Institute.

? Large leaks: Keep unauthorized personnel away.  Stay upwind.  Keep out of low areas.  

Prevent entry into sewers and confined areas.  Vapor knock down water is corrosive 

and toxic; thus it should be diked for containment.  Ensure compatible materials are 

used.

? Leaking cylinder: Only to be conducted by trained personnel.  Emergency kits are 

available for handling leaking chlorine cylinders.  Contents may also be disposed of to 

a safe out of doors area or a hood with forced ventilation.  Attach appropriate control 

valve provided with a trap or check valve and a long piece of flexible hose connected 

to the valve outlet.  Discharge the gas at a moderate rate into an adequate amount of 

about 15% aqueous sodium hydroxide or other alkali or reducing solution in suitable 

container.  When all the gas is discharged, close the cylinder valve and tag the cylinder 

as defective.  Dispose of waste according to local environmental regulations.  Also, 

see: "Section 7 - Handling and Storage".

 

Deactivating Chemicals: Sodium hydroxide; soda ash; hydrated lime - followed by a 

reducing agent.  See Incompatibles in Section 10.

 

Waste Disposal Methods: Dispose of waste material at an approved waste 

treatment/disposal facility, in accordance with applicable regulations.  Do not dispose of 

waste with normal garbage or to sewer systems.

 

Note     - Clean-up material may be a RCRA Hazardous Waste on disposal. 

- Releases are subject to CERCLA reporting requirements: RQ = 10 lb. (4.54 kg). 





SECTION 7 - HANDLING AND STORAGE 



Handling: Take all precautions to avoid personal contact.  Prevent the release of gas into 

workplace air.  Always ensure adequate ventilation in handling areas.  Locate safety 

shower and eyewash station close to ch

emical handling area.  Keep away from 

incompatibles, heat, sparks, flames and other ignition sources.  Locate safety shower and 

eyewash station fairly close to chemical handling area.  Only auxiliary valves and gauges 

designed solely for chlorine gas should be used.  Do NOT use stainless steel equipment.  

Open and shut valves to cylinders at least once a day, while cylinder is in use to avoid 

valve freezing.  Secure containers at all times.  Leaks should be fixed promptly.  Vapors 

are heavier than air.  Prevent liquid or vapor from entering sewers, sumps or pit areas.  

Vapors can create a toxic atmosphere, which may be fatal.  Use self-contained breathing 

apparatus to avoid suffocation.

 

Storage: Store in a cool, dry, well-ventilated area, out of direct sunlight, away from heat, 

away from flammable materials, incompatibles and away from process and handling areas.  

Do not store near elevators, corridors or loading docks.  Do not store below ground level or 

in confined spaces.  Storage area should be clearly identified, clear of obstruction and 

accessible only to trained and authorized personnel.  Post warning signs.  Inspect 

periodically for damage or leaks.  Keep quantities stored as small as possible.  For large-

scale storage of this material consider the installation of a leak detection system with an 

alarm.  Facilities for the emergency disposal of chlorine from leaking containers should be 

provided in storage areas.  Avoid storage of cylinders for more than six months.  Use the 

oldest first.  Compressed gas cylinders should be stored separately according to their 

chemical hazards.  This material is highly reactive.  Always store in original labeled 

cylinder, or in the type of container recommended by the manufacturer/supplier.  Keep 

cylinders tightly closed when not in use and when empty.  Cylinder valves should be 

tightly closed.  Cylinder valve caps should be properly secured.  Always check cylinder 

valve for evi

dence of damage, rust or dirt, which may inhibit operation.  Always chain or 

otherwise securely restrain cylinders in an upright position to a wall, rack or other solid 

structure when they are stored.  Store empty cylinders separate from full ones with valves 

shut off, cap secure and labeled EMPTY or "MT".  Empty containers may contain 

hazardous residues.  Outdoor cylinder storage should be weatherproofed and have proper 

drainage.  Have appropriate fire extinguishers and leak clean-up equipment in storage area.

 

Storage Temperature: Protect from temperature extremes.  (Never expose cylinders to 

temperatures higher than 52?C (125?F) or below -29?C (-20?F) unless they are designed 

for this.

 

Other Precautions: Walls, floors, shelving, fittings, lighting and ventilation systems in 

storage area should be made from materials that do not react with chlorine.  Below 121?C 

(250?F), iron, copper, steel, lead, nickel, platinum, silver and tantalum are resistant to dry 

chlorine gas or liquid.  Storage facilities should be made of fire-resistant materials.



 

SECTION 8 - EXPOSURE CONTROLS / PERSONAL PROTECTION 



PREVENTIVE MEASURES

 

Recommendations listed in this section indicate the type of equipment, which will 

provide protection against over exposure to this product.  Conditions of use, 

adequacy of engineering or other control measures, and actual exposures will dictate 

the need for specific protective devices at your workplace.

 

Engineering Controls: Local exhaust ventilation should be applied wherever there is an 

incidence of point source emissions or dispersion of regulated contaminants in the work 

area.  The most effective measures are the total enclosure of processes and the 

mechanization of handling procedures to prevent all personal contact with chlorine.  

Because of the high potential hazard associated with this substance, stringent control 

measures such as enclosure or isolation are recommended when dealing with l

arge 

quantities.  Systems must be kept "dry" to prevent metal corrosion.

 



PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT 



Eye Protection: Use full face-shield and chemical safety goggles when there is potential 

for contact.  Maintain eye wash fountain and quick-drench facilities in work area.



Skin Protection: If contact with liquid or gas is possible, then use chemical protective 

gloves, coveralls, boots and/or other resistant protective clothing.  Have a safety 

shower/eye-wash fountain readily available in the immediate work area.  Some operations 

may require the use of a chemical protective full-body encapsulating suit and respiratory 

protection.

 

Resistance of Materials for Protective Clothing: 



Guidelines for chlorine, liquid: 

? RECOMMENDED (resistance to breakthrough longer than 8 hours): Responder, 

Tychem 10,000. 



Guidelines for chlorine, gas: 

? RECOMMENDED (resistance to breakthrough longer than 8 hours): Butyl rubber, 

Neoprene, Teflon, Viton, Saranex, Barricade, CPF 3, Responder, Trellchem HPS, and 

Tychem 10,000.

? RECOMMENDED (resistance to breakthrough longer than 4 hours): Nitrile rubber, 4H 

(PE/EVAL).

? NOT RECOMMENDED for use (resistance to breakthrough less than 1 hour): 

Polyethylene, Polyvinyl Chloride.

 

Recommendations are NOT valid for very thin Natural rubber, Neoprene, Nitrile and PVC 

gloves (0.3 mm or less).

 

Recommendations are valid for permeation rates reaching 0.1 ug/cm2/min or 1 mg/m2/min 

and over.  Resistance of specific materials can vary from product to product.  Breakthrough 

times are obtained under conditions of continuous contact, generally at room temperature.  

Evaluate resistance under conditions of use and maintain clothing carefully. 



Respiratory Protection: NIOSH recommendations for chlorine concentrations in air: 

? UP TO 5 ppm: Chemical cartridge respirator with cartridge(s) to protect against 

chlorine; or supplied-air respirator (SAR).

? UP TO 10 ppm: SAR operated in a continu

ous flow mode*; or powered air-purifying 

respirator with cartridge(s) to protect against chlorine; or full-facepiece chemical 

cartridge respirator with cartridge(s) to protect against chlorine; or gas mask with 

canister to protect against chlorine; or full-facepiece self-contained breathing apparatus 

(SCBA); or full-facepiece SAR.

? Emergency or planned entry in unknown concentration or Immediately Dangerous to 

Life or Health (IDLH) conditions: Positive pressure, full-facepiece SCBA; or positive 

pressure, full-facepiece SAR with an auxiliary positive pressure SCBA.

? Escape: Mouth bit or cartridge respirator with approved chlorine cartridge; or gas mask 

with canister to protect against chlorine; or escape-type SCBA.

 

* NOTE: may require eye protection. 





EXPOSURE GUIDELINES 



PRODUCT:    Chlorine 

ACGIH Time Weighted Average            (TLV-TWA) 0.5 ppm (1.5 mg/m3) 

ACGIH Short Term Exposure Limit            (STEL) 1.0 ppm (3.0 mg/m3) 

OSHA Time Weighted Average (PEL-TWA)    1.0 ppm (3.0 mg/m3) 

Immediately Dangerous to Life and Health (IDLH): 10 ppm

 

AIHA- Emergency Response Planning Guidelines (ERPGs) 



ERPGs are for community emergency planning limits and not workplace exposure limits. 

? ERPG-1: 1 ppm

? ERPG-2: 3 ppm

? ERPG-3: 10 ppm 



The ERPG-1 is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that 

nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to 1 hr without experiencing other than mild 

transient adverse health effects or perceiving a clearly defined, objectionable odor.

 

The ERPG-2 is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that 

nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to 1 hr without experiencing or developing 

irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms, which could impair an individual's 

ability to take protective action.

 

The ERPG-3 is the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that 

nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to 1 hr without exp

eriencing or developing 

life-threatening health effects. 





SECTION 9 - PHYSICAL AND CHEMICAL PROPERTIES 



Alternate Name(s)            Molecular chlorine 

Chemical Name            Chlorine 

Chemical Family            Halogen 

Molecular Formula            Cl2 

Molecular Weight            70.9 

Appearance    Yellowish-green gas or clear amber colored liquid 

when liquefied. 

Odor                    Pungent odor 

PH                    1.5-2.0 (0.8% Aqueous Solution) 

% Volatile by Volume        100 

Vapor Pressure    673.1 kPa (6.64 atm) (97.6 psig) at (20?C); 1427 kPa 

(14.1 atm.) (207 psig) 5830 mm Hg @ 25?C (77?F) 

Vapor Density (Air = 1)        2.47 

Boiling Point                -29?F (-34?C) 

Freezing Point                -150?F (-101?C) 

Solubility (Water) 68?F        0.7% 

Specific Gravity    1.467 at 0?C (32?F) and 368.9 kPa (saturated 

liquefied gas); 0.0032 at 0?C (gas) (water = 1) 

Critical Temperature            291.2?F (143.75?C) 

Viscosity:                Liquefied gas - 0.346 mPa.s at 20?C (68?F) 





SECTION 10 - STABILITY AND REACTIVITY 



Hazardous Decomposition Products: Chlorine reacts with water to form a corrosive 

solution of  hydrochloric acid and hypochlorous acid, which can decompose to chlorine, 

oxygen and chloric acid.

 

Chemical Stability: Stable at room temperature

 

Conditions to Avoid: Temperatures greater than 121?C (250?F), and moisture.

 

Incompatibility with other Substances: Chlorine gas can react explosively with alcohols, 

ammonia and compounds, hydrocarbon gases (e.g. acetylene and ethylene), hydrogen, 

antimony trichloride and tetramethylsilane, aziridine, bromine pentafluoride, dioxygen 

difluoride, oxygen difluoride, fluorine, diborane, dichloro(methyl)arsine, disilyl oxide, 

ethylphosphine, strong reducing agents, aqueous sulfamic acid, stibine, synthetic rubber, 

tetraselenium tetranitride and white phosphorus.

 

Chlorine gas ignites on contact with mono and di-alkali metal acetylides, copper 

acetylides, halocarbons (e.g. dichloromethane), metals (e.g. finely powdered aluminum, 

brass and copper foil, iron, potassium, sod

ium, tin and titanium), non-metals (e.g. boron, 

active carbon, phosphorous and silicon), iron, uranium and zirconium carbides, diethyl 

ether, diethyl zinc, metal and non-metal hydrides, phosphorus compounds, sulfides, 

tellurium, trialkyl boranes and tungsten dioxide.

 

Liquefied chlorine can react violently, explosively or ignite on contact with carbon 

disulfide, iron, bismuth, dibutyl phthalate, drawing wax, gasoline, glycerol, linseed oil, 

white phosphorus, polydimethylsiloxane, silicones, sodium hydroxide, tin, titanium and 

vanadium powder.

 

Corrosivity To Metals: At ordinary temperatures, dry chlorine is not corrosive to most 

common metals, including steel, stainless steel, cast iron, nickel and its alloys, copper, 

brass, bronze, lead, platinum and tantalum.  Dry chlorine attacks aluminum, tin and 

titanium at ordinary temperatures and is corrosive to most metals at high temperatures 

(121?C and up).  Moist chlorine is strongly corrosive to most common metals.  Platinum, 

tantalum and titanium are resistant.  Tantalum is the most stable metal to both dry and wet 

chlorine. 



Hazardous Polymerization: Will not occur.



 

SECTION 11 - TOXICOLOGICAL INFORMATION 



TOXICOLOGICAL DATA 



Toxicological Data:    Chlorine:    LC50 rat    147 ppm (4-hour exposure) 

293 ppm (1-hour exposure) 

690 ppm (30-minute exposure) 

LC50 mouse    70 ppm (4 hr exposure) 

151 ppm (1 hr exposure) 

Mutagenicity: No human data available

 

Reproductive Effects: One report indicates that pregnant women occupationally exposed 

to chlorine had normal pregnancies. 



Teratogenicity and Fetotoxicity: No evidence

 

Synergistic Materials: Incidences of respiratory sensitization in platinum refinery workers 

increased following a spill of chlorine gas.



 

SECTION 12 - ECOLOGICAL INFORMATION 



Ecotoxicological Information: Chlorine is highly toxic to all forms of aquatic life.  There 

is no potential for bioaccumulation or bioconcentration.  Aquatic Fate: The s

tability of free 

chlorine in natural water is very low because it is a strong oxidizing agent and rapidly 

oxidizes inorganic compounds.  It also oxidizes organic compounds, but more slowly than 

inorganic compounds.

 

Fish Toxicity:        emerald shiner        LC50: 230 ug/L/96 hrs, 

rainbow trout        LC50: 172 ug/L/96hrs, 

cohoe salmon        LC50: 289 ug/L/96 hrs

 

Invertebrate Toxicity:     LC50: 637.5 ug/L/1 hour (mortality) Pacific 

oyster (Crassostrea gigas)

 

Plant Toxicity:    20 ug/L/96 days (growth) Water-milfoil 

(Myriophyllum spicatum) 





SECTION 13 - DISPOSAL CONSIDERATIONS 



Review federal, state and local government requirements prior to disposal.

 

Do not dispose of waste with normal garbage, or to sewer systems.

 

Whatever cannot be saved for recovery or recycling, including containers should be 

managed in an appropriate and approved waste disposal facility.  Processing, use or 

contamination of this product may change the waste management options.

 

RCRA: Test waste material for corrosivity, D002, prior to disposal.

2. Inventory:  The maximum intended inventory for chlorine at the SSWA Cement Hill 

Treatment Plant is 4 one ton containers.



3. Safe upper and lower limits: 



a) The temperature above which chlorine exists only as a gas, no matter how great the 

pres

sure, is 290.75 deg. F.

b) The vapor pressure of liquid chlorine at the critical temperature is 1157 psia



4. Equipment information:



A simplified process flow diagram is contained in this manual, See appendix A. Wallace 

and Tiernan chlorine leak detectors are installed in chlorine facilities at the Cement Hill 

Treatment Plant.  The alarm set-point is as follows:



Chlorine leak:        Warning     -1.0 MG/L

            High Alarm    - 3.0 MG/L



The chlorine is held within 4 each 1 ton containers.  The containers contain chlorine in a 

liquid and a gas phase.  The containers are a short ton each.  The heads are convex inward 

and forge welded to the barrel.  The sides are crimped inward at each end to form chimes 

which provide a substantial grip for lifting beams.  A removable steel valve protective 

housing protects the container valves.  Each ton container is equipped with two identical 

valves near the center of one end.  These valves are standard ton container valves.  They 

differ from the standard cylinder valve only in that they have no fusible metal plug and 

have a larger internal passage.  Each valve connects within internal eduction pipe.  The 

containers are equipped with fusible metal pressure relief devices.  Most have six fusible 

metal plugs, three in each end spaced 120? apart.  The fusible metal is designed to yield or 

melt between 158 and 165?F to relieve pressure and prevent rupture of the container in 

case of fire or other exposure to high temperature.

        

5. Engineering Controls:



a) The chlorine storage building is equipped with chlorine leak detectors that alarm when 

chlorine is detected.

b) The chlorine storage building is vented low to the ground so if a leak does occur, and 

employees are present in the building, then the leak will vent to the outside.

c) On-line cylinders are contained in a T.G.O. Technologies Containment Vessel.  A 

brochure for this equipment is included in this document. 

34

C. Hazard Review



Based o

n a review of all operating procedures, as outlined in the Injury and Illness 

Prevention Program (IIPP).  SSWA has concluded that chlorine leaks are the hazard 

involved in the chlorination process.  The following addresses the hazards of the 

chlorination process, the engineering and administrative controls applicable to chlorine 

leaks and their relationships, consequences of failure of those controls, and the 

consequences of the effects on all workplace employees in or near the process area.



1. Chemical Release



a) Continuous Release:



Chlorine can be released from a point source over a period of time.  An example of such a 

release is a leak through a faulty flange or improper connection.  Such a leak will get worse 

until the condition is corrected.  Until that time, the downwind hazards will continue.



b) Slug Release:



A slug release will occur if a vessel incurs a large puncture or rupture.  In the case of a 

puncture in the upper (vapor) portion of the vessel about one-fourth of the liquid 

(depending on the liquid temperature) will rapidly evaporate or "flash off.. 



This will cool the remaining liquid to the atmospheric boiling point.  The evaporation rate 

of the remaining liquid primarily depends on the heat input from the atmosphere.



In the case of a puncture in the liquid phase, liquid will be expelled through the hole until 

the liquid level drops to the lip of the opening.  Most of the liquid expelled will "flash off" 

as it comes out of the tank, but some may spill on the ground.  The evaporation rate of the 

spilled liquid depends on heat input from the ground and from the sun.  Reducing the 

surface area of the spill will reduce the evaporation rate.  The addition of water streams 

will provide additional heat and will increase the evaporation rate.



The area and exposure duration depend upon the total quantity released, the rate of release, 

the height of the release point, and weather conditions.  Chlorine do

wnwind can vary from 

barely detectable to high concentrations.





2. Hazards to Health



a) General



Chlorine gas is primarily a respiratory irritant it is so intensely irritating that low 

concentrations in air are readily detectable by the normal person.  At low concentrations, 

chlorine gas has an odor similar to household bleach.  As the concentrations increase from 

the level of detection from smell so does symptomatology in the exposed individual.  At 

chlorine concentrations above 5 PPM the gas is very irritating and it is unlikely that any 

person would remain in such an exposure for more than a very brief time unless she/he is 

trapped or unconscious.



b) Acute Toxicity



In concentrations near the threshold of smell, chlorine gas will, after several hours of 

exposure, cause mild irritation of the eyes of the mucous membrane of the respiratory tract.  

As concentrations increase there is an increase in the irritation effect on the eyes coughing 

mechanism and on the upper and lower respiratory tract with eventual difficulty in 

breathing.  As the duration of exposure and/or the concentration increase, the affected 

individual may become apprehensive and restless with coughing accompanied by throat 

irritation, sneezing, and excess salivation.  At higher levels there is vomiting associated 

with labored breathing.  In extreme cases difficulty in breathing can progress to the point 

of death through suffocation.



Liquid chlorine in contact with the eyes or skin will cause local irritation and/or burns.  All 

symptoms and signs result directly or indirectly from its direct irritation action.  There are 

no known systemic effects.



c) Chronic Toxicity



Low concentrations of chlorine gas in the air may have minor irritation effects or may 

produce slight symptoms after several hours of exposure, but careful examination of 

persons repeatedly exposed to such conditions reportedly has shown no permanent 

physiological effect.

The maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals 

could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or 

other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individuals ability to take 

protective action.  For chlorine, this value is 3 PPM as established by the American 

Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA).



The maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals 

could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing life-threatening 

health effects.  For chlorine, this value is 20 PPM as established by AIHA.  



1) Vegetation:



Chlorine causes bleach spots on leafy plants due to attack on chlorophyll in the 

leaf.  Mature leaves are most susceptible to chlorine injury.  Usually the plant itself 

is not destroyed although yield or growth rate may be retarded.



2) Animals:



The United States National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) 

"Registry of Toxic Effects of Chemical Substances" lists the    following 

inhalation LC's (concentration of chlorine in air lethal to 50% of the defined 

animal, exposed over the specified time period):



        Human        -840 ppm/30 minutes

        Rat        -293 ppm/60 minutes

Mouse        -137ppm/60minutes



For an unspecified species of mammal the lowest concentration of chlorine in air 

(other than LC's) which has been reported to cause death in humans or animals is 

listed as 500 ppm/5 minutes.



3. Administrative Controls:



a) All employees will be properly trained in accordance with the training outlined in this 

document.  The training is cross-referenced with SSWA's IIPP.  The training outlines 

leak control procedures as well as emergency measures in the event of a leak.

b) All employees who perform work operations around the chlorine storage areas, 

including but not limited to changing chlorine storage containers, will be equipped with 

and trained to use the pr

oper protective gear including safety suits and air packs.

c) All employees who change chlorine containers will be trained in the use of the B patch 

kits for leak repair.

d) Employees will be instructed that if a chlorine leak is uncontrollable, then the SSWA 

"Emergency Response Plan" takes effect.  Employees of SSWA will contact the 

Fairfield Fire Department and the chlorine supplier. 





D. Operating Procedures



1. DOWNLOADING TON CYLINDER FROM DELIVERY TRUCK



1) Two operators will be present, in addition to delivery person, to work on all loading 

and unloading of ton cylinders.

2) Make sure you have available all necessary equipment (see equipment list)

3) All exits to chlorine area must be unlocked and opened.  Make certain all exits are 

unblocked to insure unobstructed exit.

4) If overhead hoist is used, position hoist over cylinder, then lower and secure hoist 

lifting device to chlorine cylinder.  Also, follow instructions of delivery person 

when downloading ton cylinders from delivery truck.

5) Lift ton cylinder (no higher than necessary), position ton cylinder over rails, 

platform or trunnions and gently lower ton cylinder by putting ton hoist in reverse.

6) Disconnect hoist-lifting device from ton cylinder.

7) Before loading ton chlorine cylinder into containment vessel, the ton chlorine 

cylinder valves (V1, V2, see p. 9) must be in a vertical position before rolling 

the chlorine cylinder into the vessel.





2. LOADING TON CHLORINE CYLINDER INTO VESSEL



Caution: Operating a containment vessel can be a hazardous activity and certain 

precautions should be exercised.  All instructions should be read carefully by 

personnel engaged in installation, operation and maintenance.



Warning: Before loading the ton cylinder into the containment vessel, all moisture 

must be removed from the ton cylinder.  Carefully check the front and rear chimes 

for any water accumulation and remove by carefully drying with towels.  Interi

or of 

vessel must be kept free of moisture.



1) Position ton cylinder on roller system (with chlorine cylinder valves (V1, V2, 

in vertical position).

2) Open the vessel door past the loader support pipe.

3) Unlatch and lower the drop down roller section.

4) Before loading the ton cylinder into the vessel, use ammonia wick to leak test 

all fittings and valves on ton cylinder - including fuse plugs at rear of cylinder.

5) Before loading the ton cylinder into the vessel, position the interior supply line 

to position for loading (out of the way of the ton being rolled in).  Caution: Do 

not fold, over flex, or torque the flex line.

6) Carefully push ton cylinder into the vessel until it gently stops against the rear 

of the vessel.

7) Lift the drop down roller section past the support pipe and re-latch drop down 

roller section in secured, upright position.

8) Secure the ton cylinder within the vessel by bolting into place with the two (2) 

"C" shaped locking clamps located at the front and bottom of the vessel.





3. LEAKS -MINOR AND MAJOR



1) If major leak occurs, refer to Response Procedures.

2) If minor leak occurs, notify support personnel and secure leak.

3) If leak is detected within sealed vessel, refer to Emergency Procedure when 

Ton Containment Vessel has Pressure on Gauge or Pressure Check Valve 

Indicates Chlorine Release within Vessel).





4. CONNECTING THE TON CYLINDER GAS SUPPLY TO INTERIOR SUPPLY 

LINE



1) Remove cylinder valve protector cover from ton cylinder.

2) Make certain chlorine ton cylinder valves (V1, V2,) on ton are in vertical 

position.

3) While holding an ammonia wick next to the top chlorine ton cylinder gas 

supply valve (V1) remove cap from cylinder valve.

4) CAUTION!  Never remove cap from bottom (liquid) or lower chlorine 

cylinder valve (V2).  Only remove cap from the top gas chlorine cylinder 

supply valve (V1).

5) Inspect the face of the top cylinder chlorine supply valve (V1) to insure a c

lean 

and proper connection to the interior supply line yoke adapter.

6) Inspect the interior supply line for kinks or damage-replace if necessary.

7) Inspect the face of the interior supply line yoke adapter to insure a clean and 

proper connection.

8) Always install a new connection gasket, making sure the old gasket has been 

removed.  IMPORTANT, use only one gasket.

9) Connect the interior supply line, connect adapter fitting, using a proper ton 

wrench to tighten the yoke, to the top (gas) ton cylinder supply valve (V1).

10) While holding an ammonia wick at the yoke connection, use the ton wrench to 

slightly open (1/8 turn, max) the top chlorine cylinder gas supply valve (V1) 

and immediately re-close the top chlorine cylinder gas supply valve (V1).

11) Use the ammonia wick to leak test the entire supply line (interior and exterior) 

on vessel, including all fittings and connections.



NOTE: The above leak tests must be performed with every new cylinder 

connection.



12) Only after confirming there are no leaks, reopen the top chlorine ton cylinder 

gas supply one (1) full turn and leave the ton wrench connected on the valve 

(V1).

13) Recheck all internal and external connections and fitting on vessel and chlorine 

cylinder supply valve (V1) with ammonia wick to confirm that there are not 

leaks before closing and sealing the containment vessel door.





5. CLOSING AND SEALING THE CONTAINMENT VESSEL DOOR



1) Inspect the door and vessel faces of the closure and wipe clean any dust or 

debris from both faces of the closure.

2) Inspect the door "O" ring and wipe clean, making sure the "O" ring has no cuts, 

tears or gouges.  Replace of necessary.

3) Close and secure the vessel door.  IMPORTANT!  Use the proper two- (2) 

setting torque procedures.

4) The first torque value is 150 ft/lbs.  The final torque value is 225-ft lbs.  The 

proper tightening pattern must be followed.

5) Use only halogenated grease to keep vessel door facin

gs and "O" ring 

lubricated with a light coating - wipe off all excess grease.

6) Vessel door bolts must be kept lubricated for easy operation and rust 

prevention.





6. PROCESSING GAS FROM THE TON VESSEL



1) After the door has been properly sealed, open the exterior supply line manual 

valve (B1) one (1) full turn.  (The vacuum regulator is connected to this valve 

(B1)

2) Make sure vac/pressure gauge valve (A2) is in open position.

3) Make sure pressure check valve (A1) is in closed position with cap on valve.

4) Check connection at exterior chlorine valve (B1) and vacuum regulator with 

ammonia wick to insure there are no leaks.

5) The system is now operational or on standby, depending on the status of the 

vacuum regulator and the fail safe valve (B4)

6) The scale system should now be inspected to insure proper weight and settings.





7. OPENING THE VESSEL DOOR TO REMOVE CHLORINE TON CYLINDER



Warning: Do not attempt to open the closure until the vessel has been relieved of all 

internal pressure.  Opening under pressure may result in injury to persons and 

damage to equipment.



Important: Before opening the vessel door check the vacuum/pressure gauge on 

vessel to see if it reads pressure in the vessel.  Do not open door when gauge shows 

pressure.  If gauge shows pressure, see, Section H Emergency Procedures.



1) If gauge shows no pressure, slightly open pressure check valve (A1) on exterior 

of vessel and check with ammonia wick to insure no chlorine is contained 

within the vessel.  (Also, listen for pressure release or sound or indication of 

odor.)  Reclose pressure check valve (A1).

2) After confirming there is no chlorine contained within the vessel, loosen the 18-

vessel door retaining bolts on containment vessel door in proper sequence using 

3/4" drive ratchet with 1-13/16" socket.

3) After loosening, swing retaining bolts up and out of retaining lugs; swing door 

open carefully - do not damage door seal.

4) Turn

off the ton supply valve V, then remove the interior supply line from ton 

cylinder supply valve (V1) using ton wrench.  NOTE: a small amount of 

residual chlorine will be in the interior supply line.  Immediately plug the 

opening on the interior supply line with a "tee"to prevent moisture from 

entering the supply system.

5) Install cap on ton cylinder supply chlorine valve (V1), making sure cap has 

only one gasket.  Then, install ton cylinder valve cover protecting bonnet on ton 

cylinder.  Use ton wrench for both procedures.

6) Remove two (2)-locking clamps located at the front and bottom of the vessel.

7) Place the interior supply line into position for unloading (out of the way of the 

ton being rolled out).

8) Unlatch drop down roller section and lower to horizontal position.

9) Remove empty ton chlorine cylinder from vessel by using removal clamp and 

secure cylinder in storage area.





8. EMERGENCY PROCEDURES



WHEN TON CONTAINMENT VESSEL HAS PRESSURE ON GAUGE OR 

PRESSURE CHECK VALVE INDICATES CHLORINE RELEASE WITHIN 

VESSEL



To evacuate all chlorine from vessel:



1) Continue to process chlorine into the system until the chlorine ton cylinder is 

completely empty, and the vacuum/pressure gauge has a vacuum reading.

2) Once the vacuum/pressure gauge has had vacuum reading for 30 minutes, the 

vessel is ready to be opened.  Relieve the vacuum by opening the pressure 

check valve (A1).  There should be suction at valve when the vacuum is 

relieved.  Close the pressure check valve, and then recheck the vacuum/pressure 

gauge to insure that there is not a pressure reading.  Then follow the normal 

opening of vessel door and unloading procedures.



IF YOU ARE UNABLE TO COMPLETELY EVACUATE VESSEL THROUGH 

THE PRIMARY SUPPLY SYSTEM, THEN YOU MUST SWITCH TO RIG 

ALTERNATIVE SUPPLY SYSTEM TO COMPLETE TOTAL EVACUATION. 



3) Close the external chlorine supply valve (B1) (the vacuum regulator is attached 

to this valve).

4) Close ex

ternal chlorine supply valve (B1) attached to the vacuum regulator.

5) Remove vacuum regulator from chlorine supply valve (B1) and re-attach 

vacuum regulator to alternative exterior chlorine supply valve (B2) on vessel.  

Make sure connection is proper and gasket is in place.

6) Open alternative exterior chlorine supply ball valve (B3).  Check with ammonia 

wick to be certain there is no leak.  After checking' open alternative chlorine 

supply valve (B2) slightly.  Check with ammonia to insure no leaks, then open 

valve (B2) one full turn.

7) Operate vacuum regulator and continue to operate until indicator on 

vacuum/pressure gauge on vessel reads 4" to 10" vacuum.

8) Shut down alternative chlorine supply valve (B2) and wait no less than thirty 

(30) minutes to insure vacuum in vessel holds constant.

9) After making certain vacuum in vessel has held constant, relieve vacuum in 

vessel by opening pressure check valve (A1) on vessel.  There should be 

suction at valve when vacuum is released.  Re-check to insure no chlorine 

pressure is indicated on gauge after relieving vacuum on vessel.  Then, follow 

normal opening of vessel door and unloading procedures.



IMPORTANT: Never open vessel door until you are absolutely certain that no 

chlorine release is contained within the vessel.





9. RECOMMENDED TOOLS & EQUIPMENT ON SITE



1) Two (2) ton cylinder wrenches.

2) Two (2) angled ton cylinder wrenches.

3) Ammonia wick and ammonia solution to check for leaks.

4) Pneumonic wrench with 3/4" drive or 1/2" to 3/4" adapter, special torque 

wrench from 60 ft/lbs. to 300 ft/lbs.

5) Torque wrench 3/4" drive with 1 13/16" socket for door bolts.

6) Tie down devices to secure ton cylinders when in storage.

7) Grease gun for halogenated grease.

8) Halogenated grease for trunnion lubrication.

9) Gaskets for ton chlorine cylinder valve yoke adapter connections and valve 

caps.





10. RECOMMENDED SPARE PARTS ON SITE



1) One (1) "O" ring for vessel d

oor.

2) One (1) interior supply line.

3) Two (2) ton chlorine cylinder valves.

4) One (1) yoke.

5) One (1) yoke adapter.

6) One (1) angled ton wrench.









11. RECOMMENDED SAFETY EQUIPMENT ON SITE



1) Two (2) self-contained breathing apparatus.

2) Emergency ton repair kit ("B Kit").

3) Protective clothing.





E. Training



Safe handling of chlorine depends upon the effectiveness of employee training, proper 

safety instructions, intelligent supervision, and the use of suitable equipment.  It is the 

responsibility of supervisors to train employees how to use personal protective and other 

safety equipment.  It is the responsibility of employees to properly use the equipment 

provided.  Training classes will be conducted to maintain a high degree of competence in 

handling procedures.  Employees will be informed of the hazards that may result from 

improper handling of chlorine.  They will be trained to prevent leaks and instructed 

regarding proper action to take in case leaks occur.  Each employee will know what to do 

in an emergency and will be informed as to first aid measures.



Each employee whose primary duties include the operating or maintenance of a process 

and each employee before working in a newly assigned process shall be trained in an 

overview of the process and in the operating procedures.  Training will coincide with 

training currently being conducted under the Employee IIPP Program.



Every year or if processes change, each employee involved as listed above will undergo 

refresher training.



Each employee undergoing training as listed above will be required to sign documentation 

that they have completed the above training.  The training documents will be kept with the 

IIPP training documents.





F. Contractors

                 

In the event that outside contractors are needed to work on the chlorine system, SSWA 

wil1normally contact Borges and Mahoney of Vallejo California.  In the event other work 

must b

e contracted the following steps will be taken:



1. Inform the contractor working on or near the chlorine system of the known potential 

toxic release hazards related to the contractors work and will require that the contractor 

has trained their employees to a level adequate to safely perform their job.

2. Explain to the contractor the provisions of the Emergency Action Plan listed below.

3. Require the contractor to assure that each of their employees have received training to 

safely perform their job and that the contract employee shall comply with all applicable 

work practices and safety rules of the facility contained in the IIPP.





G. Mechanical Integrity



In the event employees realize potentially faulty or unsafe equipment, during routine 

inspections or daily operations, they are required to document in writing the potential 

problem.  The IIPP contains forms for such reporting.  SSWA will respond within 72 hours 

to the employee regarding the disposition of the employees concerns.



The chlorine facility is visually inspected 4 times per shift.



All chlorinators and regulators will be cleaned and inspected annually in accordance with 

SSWA "Cement Hill Treatment Plant Operations Plan".



Any deficiencies noted during the inspection process will be corrected in a timely manner.



Any modified, repaired, or fabricated equipment will meet design specifications and 

applicable codes existing at the time of manufacture.  Applicable codes include the 

American Society of Mechanical Engineers, the American Petroleum Institute, the 

American Institute of Chemical Engineers, the American National Standards Institute, the 

American Society of Testing and Materials, the National Board of Boiler and Pressure 

Vessel Inspectors and the National Fire Protection Association.





H. Management of Change



In the event of a change in the process, for the exception of the replacement of parts or 

equipment in kind, the following will occur:

1. The technical basis for the proposed change will be reviewed and approved by the 

appropriate individuals; in this cases the Superintendent.

2. The impact of the change of health and safety will be given to affected employees for 

review.

3. The affected employees will be informed regarding the modification of operating 

procedures, if any.

4. All affected employees will be notified regarding the necessary time period for the 

change or modification.

5. Employees involved in the process being modified will be informed of and trained in, 

the change in the process prior to the start up of the modified process.

6. In the event the modification results in a change to the process safety information, that 

information will be updated immediately.

7. In the event the modification results in a change to the operating procedures, that 

information will be updated immediately.





I. Incident Investigation



In the event of an occurrence, the following procedures will be completed:



1. An investigation into the incident will be initiated by the superintendent no later than 

48 hours following the incident.

2. The investigation will be conducted by a team of individuals knowledgeable in the 

process involved in the incident.

3. The investigation team will submit a written report to the superintendent with the 

following information:

a) Date of incident.

b) Date the investigation began.

c) Description of the incident.

d) The factors contributing to the incident.

e) Any recommendations for change resulting from the investigation.

4. The incident report will be reviewed with all operating and maintenance personnel 

whose work assignments are within the area where the incident occurred.

5. SSWA will promptly address and resolve the report findings and recommendations 

made by the incident investigation team.  SSWA will implement the report 

recommendations or take action to prevent the reoccurrence as soon as possible.





J. Compliance Audit

s

 

Every three years the Municipal & Industrial Operations Superintendent will review and 

verify that the procedures and practices developed and detailed under this RMP continue to 

be adequate and are being followed.  Documentation of deficiencies and corrections will be 

retained at the Offices of the Solano Irrigation District.





K. Pre-start up Review



The Municipal & Industrial Operations Superintendent shall perform a pre-start up safety 

review for any new or modified stationary sources or equipment used in the chlorination 

process when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process 

safety information.



The pre-start up safety review shall confirm that new construction or equipment is in 

accordance with design specifications.  Safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency 

procedures are in place and adequate.  Training of each employee involved in operating a 

process has been completed. 





L. Employee Participation Plan



The Municipal & Industrial Operations Superintendent Shall consult with employees and 

their representatives on the development and implementation of all process safety as it 

relates to any RMP regulated substances.  In particular, employees will participate in 

process hazard analysis and be consulted as to how the other elements of the prevention 

program are carried out.  At a minimum, total process review will be done and documented 

with all employees annually.





M. Hot work Permits   



Hot work refers to spark or flame producing operations such as welding, brazing, metal 

cutting, grinding, sand blasting, etc.  The Municipal & Industrial Operations 

Superintendent will issue a hot work permit describing the hazards of the work to be done 

and the needed precautions to prevent fires.  The permit shall also indicate the date 

authorized for the work to be done and identify the object on which the hot work will be 

performed.  The permit will be kept on file until com

pletion of the hot work operations.  



    

IV. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  



A. Chlorine Leaks



As soon as there is any indication of the presence of chlorine in the air, immediate steps 

will be taken to correct the conditions.



Chlorine leaks always get worse if they are not promptly corrected.  When a chlorine leak 

occurs, authorized, trained personnel equipped with suitable respiratory protection, will 

investigate and take action.  No person should work alone on a chlorine leak.  All other 

persons should be kept away from the affect area until the leak has been stopped and the 

residual chlorine dispersed.  If the emission is extensive, all persons in the path of the 

fumes should be evacuated by the proper authorities.



Potentially exposed persons should move to a point upwind of the leak.  Because chlorine 

is heavier than air, higher elevations are preferable.  To escape in the shortest time, persons 

already in contaminated areas should move crosswind.  When outdoors without respiratory 

protection, a wet handkerchief or cloth will reduce the effects of exposure.



If inside a building and evacuations seems to be impractical, all windows should be closed 

and air conditioners and air intake systems turned off.  Personnel should retreat to the 

highest point of the building on the side away from the break.



If the leak is of a serious nature, the SSWA "Emergency Response Plan" will be initiated.  

When calling for assistance the following information should be provided:



1) Company name, address, telephone number, and the person to contact for 

further information.

2) Description of the emergency.

3) Travel directions to the site.

4) Type and size of container involved.

5) Corrective measures being applied.

6) Other pertinent information regarding the weather conditions, injuries etc.



If the leak is serious the local Authorities must be notified to effect any necessary 

evacuation.  All personnel at the Cement Hill Tr

eatment Plant who are involved in the 

handling of chlorine or could be involved in an emergency will be trained in emergency 

procedures as out lined in training section of this document.





B. Fire



If a fire is present or threatened, chlorine containers should be moved away from the fire.  

If a non-leaking container cannot be moved, it should be kept cool by spraying water on it.  

If the container is leaking, water should not be used.  Chlorine and water react, and acids 

are formed that will corrode the container and the leak quickly will get worse.  However, 

where several containers are involved and some are leaking, it may be prudent to use water 

to prevent rupture of the non-leaking containers.  Additional Information regarding 

emergency planning is located within the SSWA Emergency Response Plan.









C. CEMENT HILL WATER TREATMENT PLANT

RESPONSE PROCEDURES FOR CHLORINE LEAKS



WHEN HANDLING ANY CHOLORINE LEAK, THERE MUST BE A MINIMUM 

OF TWO AUTHORIZED CHLORINE PERSONNEL RESPONDING TO LEAK.



A. The following positions are authorized chlorine response personnel:

1. Water Treatment Operator Chief

2. Water Treatment Operator Shift

3. M&I Operations Supervisor

4. M&I Operations Superintendent



B. Upon discovery of a chlorine leak and if determined by operator on duty to be a minor 

leak, prior to proceeding to corrective actions, a request for leak response assistance 

will be made to authorized chlorine response personnel in numerical order of section 

(A) until a second authorized response person is at the leak site for assistance.



C. An example of corrective action responses to be taken are as follows but not limited to:



1. Donning self contained breathing apparatus.

2. If chlorine leak is in liquid form, attempt to turn the container so that the leak is at 

the top of the cylinder, thereby the chlorine leaking will be in a gaseous state.

3. Insert leaking cylinder into containment vessel for future use in treatmen

t 

processes.

4. If unable to insert leaking cylinder into containment vessel, neutralize cylinder leak 

area with (B) kit application.

5. If determined to be a major leak, operator will call the following in order: 

    

1) Rich Everts                (707) 426-4548

2) Ben Latonio                (707) 429-9032

3) Al Taglieri                    (707) 447-7935

4) Carol Ramirez                (707) 447-9230

5) Fairfield Fire                         (707) 428-7300

6) Pioneer America's, Inc.            (925) 280-2600

7) Chem Trac                    (800) 424-9300

8) Solano County Department OES        (707) 421-7090



Fire Department may or may not elect to take lead role in securing leak.  If the Fire 

Department elects to only support District staff, proceed with corrective action responses 

outlined in Emergency Procedures section.







D. If an individual is overcome or burned by chlorine, the following steps shall be 

immediately taken:



1) Immediately remove individual from the contaminated area.

2) Call 911 for medical assistance.

3) If breathing is impaired, start CPR and do not stop until proper authorities 

arrive and take over first aid.

4) Eyes: utilize HAWs equipment.  Hold eyelids apart and flush for approximately 

fifteen minutes.  Seek medical attention.

5) Skin: Remove exposed individual and place under HAWs shower.  Remove 

contaminated clothing while shower is running.  Do not attempt to neutralize 

chlorine burns with chemicals, salves, ointments or soap.  Seek medical 

attention.

6) Inhalation: If individual is breathing, place victim in a comfortable position 

and keep still and at rest until medical attention arrives.





V. HAZARD ASSESSMENT



A. Five Year Accident History/ Reporting

 

As of the date of this plan, no accidental releases of chlorine have occurred resulting in 

deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, 

evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





B. External Event Analysis



The external event revie

wed due to its high probability of occurrence was an earthquake 

event.  The analysis methodology selected is the "What-if" analysis.



In the event that an earthquake with a significant level of magnitude were to occur at the 

Cement Hill Water Treatment Plant what types of failure may take place in relation to the 

chlorination equipment operation and spill containment processes?  



1. What if the chlorine cylinders housed within the containment vessels were too 

severe the interior chlorine transfer lines to the exterior vacuum regulators 

during an earthquake?



To minimize the possibility of this occurring the chlorine cylinders are fastened to the 

interior containment structure wall via welded C-type clamps at the cylinders chimes.  

Also, original copper type "pigtail"feed lines were replaced with Monel 400 transfer hoses 

with type 302 stainless steel guard.  If these were to fail the escaping gas from this hose 

would be contained within the containment vessel. 



2. What if an earthquake induced power outage was to occur?



All ancillary emergency electrical equipment for the containment vessels (leak detectors, 

shut-off valves, alarms) are powered during electrical outages with on-site diesel powered 

electric generators.  If for some reason these generators do not respond as designed all 

chlorine delivery will be automatically stopped via back-up nitrogen supplied shut-off 

valves.



3. What if the containment vessels were to be moved from their foundations and 

exterior ancillary equipment on the containment vessels were to be damaged or 

detached? 



The containment vessels are mounted to an 8-inch concrete slab with 12, _-inch sized 

stainless steel bolts.  If these were to fail allowing the vessel to move severing the chlorine 

transfer piping to process, the automatic vacuum operated chlorine regulators would close 

stopping the flow.  Consequences of failure or damage to the automatic shut-off valve are 

described in t

he RMP description of "Alternative release data analysis" for a ?-inch 

opening in the vessel.



Operations staff is trained biannually in the use of self contained breathing apparatus and 

the application of emergency leak repair kits for use on one ton chlorine cylin
